TheHeroShep 16-Dec-21 08:13 AM
Reposting this in this thread because this is the summary of my thoughts on the matter As many of you know I was extremely against burning. A couple considérations for why staking could be actually good (I was initially against staking now I’m leaning towards it being good) 1. If staking is exclusively until the marketplace is released, it provides price stability without the team having to deal with putting their own $ on the line for liquidity 2. Until the marketplace is released, honestly NCR is a bit overvalued because you can’t really use it yet 3. If a chunk of tokens are explicitly reserved for the team to sell after the fact, they may actually make more money if the price goes to above $29 & they could announce they’re going to sell the coins in a log curve similar to the current mint structure they have the same effect but can technically be ‘out of the ico’ and be listed on a CEX 4. Actually does bring in long term crypto investors 5. There is a non-zero risk that as price rises with an ongoing ICO the team may have to deploy a lot of $ to buyback NCR below mint price to live up to their promise. That use of funds could be potentially very detrimental to the project depending on how much is needed Big caveat. I think staking should die as soon as marketplace is released. With that said I think the details of how the staking would occur are really important and the community deserves at least that information even if the context on why this is so critical itself can’t be revealed at the moment. (Due to the confirmed NDA or otherwise). Also worth mentioning, Karel likely has a big reason for doing this. He knowingly riling up the community that he knows is a bit fed up with this already. Great summary of that take here https://discord.com/channels/402159838827905024/920998371777478696/921059335159840808 (edited)

Isambard FA 16-Dec-21 08:43 AM
If you're going to provide staking the rewards should come from a sustainable source of revenue not a finite treasury amount. Then staking becomes the equivalent of holding shares and receiving a dividend. The rewards then typically come from transaction fees, license fees etc. and you have holders vested in the long-term success of the product not just until the treasury runs out.

Less likely to happen when the staking drawdown is over more than a year. santa-fe-slim 16-Dec-21 09:10 AM
I don't know how many of you have participated in staking on ETH or DeFi, but I have locked Aave and some other things on ETH and you end-up loosing a ton on each transaction. It would be smart to use this opportunity to diversify networks by combining entering staking with a bridging option in the same transaction. As I said on other thread: Regarding staking, if this occurs, it would be good to include the option to bridge to other network(s) in this ETH transaction to save stakers money entering into and out of staking (no matter what ETH does) and promote liquidity on other networks such as Polygon with lower gas fees. This would support the environmental mission of Neos and future NFT minting on secondary solution networks. If not, depending on the price of ETH unstaking gas fees could be expensive in the future and profits could go to miners/ETH burn rather than NEOs or stakers. Also, please consider realistic lockup periods/rewards so stakers could use their NEOs to benefit or build Neos when it becomes useful in the market or other areas, i.e. allow shorter lockups with good rewards for user flexibility.

low lockup periods are fine in this case because I can't imagine there are anythings that the "stake" can be "slashed" for (so there's no need to hold it during withdrawal in case of misbehavior) but that just means that the only tools we have to align incentive is the actual mechanism we should use for staking (what behavior do we reward) and the lockup period for rewards (short term is constant supply pressure, long term is delayed pressure, lots of protocols have staking curves - the longer you lock up, the better the reward rate) (edited)

Feynt 16-Dec-21 09:30 AM
I'm in favour of staking. If NCR's purpose is to be used as a primary in game market currency, having a burn (as previously discussed, and rejected apparently) makes for a short term gain with a major sell off on the horizon. A stake until the marketplace and DRM on items sold exists sounds like a way to force investment by those interested in Neos as a platform, or as a means of selling/trading goods. It'll slow the purchase of outside investors who are looking to capitalise on a cheap, quick coin on the rise. But honestly that's better for the system long term, as when the system is ready to go and people can start working on making Neos object sales their career, the majority of people invested will have a proper interest in the security of the system as a whole.

santa-fe-slim 16-Dec-21 10:10 AM
Whatever the opinion of the projects themselves, ICP and Bloktopia offer some interesting reward ideas for staking. With ICP they offer voting rights in the DAO with lock-up and the ability to deligate these voting rights. Bloktopia had an issue with high valuation before they sold their NFTs for land/storefronts in the mall, so they created a staking called Rebok which allows stakers to share the benefits of NFT ownership with a larger group. As a method for rewarding early adaptors and holders with less money it is a good idea, as the investor whales can't dominate the NFT aspect as much. NEOs doesn't yet have NFTs and shouldn't have land, but there are alternatives to this model NEOs could adapt. It depends what thet want to do, but should be planned out in advance of staking. (edited)

Feynt 16-Dec-21 10:27 AM
A consequence I can think of for allowing NCR to be bought and traded out of Neos is less in game currency for future use. Let's say there's an equal split, 50/50 of actual creators and simple investment folk and we consider this "normal". If the shift goes 80/20 for investors vs creators, the value of currency in game increases dramatically and one credit becomes worth more and more. Eventually though as people cash out because of their value in game being so high, the investor side claims more and more because in game prices are on the rise, until there's almost nothing in game and an unsustainable market occurs and prices crash because nobody can trade anymore.

Feynt 16-Dec-21 11:25 AM
So an example on SL, for those unfamiliar with the platform, a goods purchase in a non-working state is some avatars with minor flaws (such as unnoticed mesh holes or unassigned UVs in hard to see places that someone did see). In the cases of good content creators (like in the real world), you provide proof of your existing purchase, they will gift you a free replacement of the fixed version. In the bad cases, yes, you get a good you can't fix and it remains in a flawed state indefinitely. In these cases, clever hacker types have reverse engineered those things and fixed them by creating their own object based on the original. They are considered the owner in SL's system because they reuploaded all the things. But this, too, reflects flawed goods in reality where a manufacturer won't honour replacing the original, as people resort to breaking down their item and fixing the flaw themselves in a good many cases. Ideally you would be sold a referenced copy of a good template, and changes to the template could reflect on the goods copy as an activatable state by the owner. I can see people not wanting to update their copy, but that could lead to unfortunate circumstances where an item is bought full permission accidentally and the creator wanting to correct that by making it non-copyable and people with the copyable version saying "no thanks".

Feynt 16-Dec-21 12:59 PM
Basic economics says if you have less of a thing to circulate, that thing is worth more. It's the promise that more of that thing being made that sets its value lower. So if they burn what's left, everyone's NCR value instantly jumps because that's it, you have the actual percentage now, rather than the theoretical percentage when minting finishes.
So if you had 1 of 100 potential things, let's say, that's 1%. If the maker of that thing said, "you know what, forget it, we've made 50, that's all.", you now own 2%.

It's... more complicated than that. The bigger point with most crypto boils down to transparency, Anonymity, and being publically accessible. Alden 16-Dec-21 05:33 PM
Bringing it full, circle -- I would like to restate the merits of staking vs. not staking: Ending the ICO and transitioning to a staking model would stabilize the price of NCR, allowing for gradual growth and a longer time horizon for the Neos team. It would also give Karel greater control over the liquidity and the ability to use the funds generated thus far by the ICO for purposes other than maintaining the ICO such as paying Neos team members, hiring new ones, and generally building the Neos team into a Neos company. In contrast finishing the ICO stands to generate more capital for the stockpile and maintains community confidence in the team for honoring the original terms of the whitepaper. That is what is being considered in this thread with respect to the poll. (edited)

Alden 16-Dec-21 10:15 PM
To give a quick recap of https://discord.com/channels/402159838827905024/920998371777478696/921229128433270804 Karel issues NCR manually as mint orders come in. This causes a delay between the market price of NCR and the mint price of NCR. Once the mint hits equilibrium, a huge sell-off occurs as people begin to adopt arbitrage, this brings the price of NCR nearly back down to where it was until Karel fronts more liquidity -- this locks up capital that could otherwise be spent on developing Neos and growing the platform. Then the price stagnates for some time. Then the cycle resumes. (edited)

Minting does not typically occur when the mint is above the market price because it is disadvantageous
Alden
Minting does not typically occur when the mint is above the market price because it is disadvantageous
Xcryptic589 16-Dec-21 10:18 PM

Alden 16-Dec-21 10:19 PM
So if we're to finish the ICO, we're assuming that the market price is at least the mint price when minting is occurring -- which means that the price gets pumped while mint orders are going in
This historically has resulted in the market price rising above the mint in a spike that only closes off when the mint gets adjusted up

But this process happens manually, and as more capital comes in, there is a larger delay between when the mint orders are placed and when the mint price is updating
Once the mint hits equilibrium i.e. once Karel has distributed all of the NCR for the batch(es) the mint price gets adjusted up accordingly

The risk of staking is that you lock yourself out, even in the event of the token crashing. If you see a crash incoming but still have it staked you will be unable to sell, which means you end up actually losing money even after your newly acquired tokens. This is something that you have to do your own risk assessment and calculations on. For me, I will not be participating in staking because the risk outweighs the potential gain in my situation.

Alden 17-Dec-21 04:15 PM
How does staking de-incentivize content creation in Neos? This should stabilize the price of NCR for the long term and lock in value from the holders -- which will allow people to purchase NCR at a more predictable price. This will enable more reliable pricing of goods and services within Neos, and make transacting value in and out of Neos much easier. Ultimately the base units of Neos Credits are not in NCR -- they're in "noi" or 0.000000000000000001 NCR. It would be trivial to move the decimal and transact in noi instead of NCR. Increasing the price predictability by stabilizing it with staking will make something like putting NCR in your account that you can hold on to for a while before exchanging for goods or services in-verse possible. Otherwise, we stay on this spiking model, and to even conduct reasonable business you have to start in a base currency, convert that into NCR, exchange the NCR in-verse, and then convert it back out of NCR. That would be the only way you could guarantee approximately equivalent exchanges of value, and it would mean that NCR is just an unnecessary piece of the economy -- because why not use a stablecoin instead like USDC? This will lock up value and stabilize the value of the currency, making it possible to even use as a currency in the first place.

Alden
How does staking de-incentivize content creation in Neos? This should stabilize the price of NCR for the long term and lock in value from the holders -- which will allow people to purchase NCR at a more predictable price. This will enable more reliable pricing of goods and services within Neos, and make transacting value in and out of Neos much easier. Ultimately the base units of Neos Credits are not in NCR -- they're in "noi" or 0.000000000000000001 NCR. It would be trivial to move the decimal and transact in noi instead of NCR. Increasing the price predictability by stabilizing it with staking will make something like putting NCR in your account that you can hold on to for a while before exchanging for goods or services in-verse possible. Otherwise, we stay on this spiking model, and to even conduct reasonable business you have to start in a base currency, convert that into NCR, exchange the NCR in-verse, and then convert it back out of NCR. That would be the only way you could guarantee approximately equivalent exchanges of value, and it would mean that NCR is just an unnecessary piece of the economy -- because why not use a stablecoin instead like USDC? This will lock up value and stabilize the value of the currency, making it possible to even use as a currency in the first place.

Jam10o 18-Dec-21 06:44 AM
I like to larp as a systempunk sometimes, and I see the problem to be in the nuance of how this happens. Staking in the naive, worst-case, way of conceiving it definitely does sound like a horrible idea for a token intended to be a currency (just like a deflationary token is in the first place), but the nuance is that: staking isn't actually part of the design of the token (which has no real design tbf) it's just tacked on at the end and will necessarily be finite. we could make any kind of nonsense mechanism and call it staking, some of them would even be good [read: better than the naive implementation, not objectively good] ideas, like a Token Curated Registry to support creators and discover them, or something that incentivises some kind of positive activity as a prerequisite to stake. Staking is vague so let's run with it. Nobody implementing any of this is ever going to read this, or any number of discussions in this channel though, so we're probably going to get some naive and directionless implementation that isn't actually designed to accomplish the/any intended goal. Someone please prove me wrong.

Tangle 18-Dec-21 02:54 PM
Quick math to work off of: assume this: 9.6m tokens remain. 3 year staking program. 3.2m tokens released each year. if on the high side 20m tokens get staked, then each year, each NCR token staked would receive an additional 0.16 NCR, so after one year you would have 1.16 NCR for each staked. 10m, 1.32 NCR at the end. (there can be several ways to set up staking, but lets imagine this on a linear release for simplicity) Now, ask yourself what extra benefits are you getting from staking? What does that mean for you? Traditionally, Staking is designed for a Proof of Stake validation model, to help secure the network. This does not apply here. Otherwise you would do so for voting rights, or to receive a dividend. Not sure either of those are on the table hear either. Staking will help lock up tokens, therefore having less supply for the market to dump. Often can help with price appreciation. But if there is not many stakers, there may be more dumpers, therefore washing away the increased value of NCR for those who are locked up. Open to hear from others as to why they would be interested in staking their NCR

Alden 18-Dec-21 06:20 PM
Reading back a few hours, I saw there were several questions about the benefits of staking so I wanted to attempt to clarify a bit, since up until now I've mostly been explaining why ending the ICO is potentially beneficial. Another quick aside I will be avoiding speculation on how staking might be implemented for NCR. Also this analogy is not 1:1. It is simply intended to illustrate the fundamental ideas behind staking. We can think of staking NCR on the network like having an old-school savings account at a brick and mortar bank. You deposit "cash" at the bank. The bank then keeps a portion of that cash on hand and invests the rest. That investment generates a return for the bank. Then the bank distributes a percentage of the profits in the form of "savings account interest". That interest is now cash that the account holder can withdraw and use. With staking it's very similar with the notable caveat of having to guarantee that you won't ask for that money back before a certain minimum amount of time has passed. The minimum time rule allows the "bank" to conduct its investments without having to worry about needing to liquidate those assets on demand.

Reading back a few hours, I saw there were several questions about the benefits of staking so I wanted to attempt to clarify a bit, since up until now I've mostly been explaining why ending the ICO is potentially beneficial. Another quick aside I will be avoiding speculation on how staking might be implemented for NCR. Also this analogy is not 1:1. It is simply intended to illustrate the fundamental ideas behind staking. We can think of staking NCR on the network like having an old-school savings account at a brick and mortar bank. You deposit "cash" at the bank. The bank then keeps a portion of that cash on hand and invests the rest. That investment generates a return for the bank. Then the bank distributes a percentage of the profits in the form of "savings account interest". That interest is now cash that the account holder can withdraw and use. With staking it's very similar with the notable caveat of having to guarantee that you won't ask for that money back before a certain minimum amount of time has passed. The minimum time rule allows the "bank" to conduct its investments without having to worry about needing to liquidate those assets on demand.
Alden 18-Dec-21 06:20 PM
So how does this impact users wanting NCR for in-verse utility? When the price of NCR spikes up, large account holders are more likely to sell. If they do, a spike down follows, which triggers a buying event from investors trying to "buy the dip", and now we're back to the price spiking up from demand -- it's a positive feedback loop. If we offer an incentive like staking interest though, holders (large and small) are likely to lock up some of their cash for that reward. This will prevent them from being able to sell for a guaranteed amount of time (penalties currently undecided). In theory and generally in practice too, that means no major price dips. This is good for in-verse users because it adds predictability.
1
Alden
So how does this impact users wanting NCR for in-verse utility? When the price of NCR spikes up, large account holders are more likely to sell. If they do, a spike down follows, which triggers a buying event from investors trying to "buy the dip", and now we're back to the price spiking up from demand -- it's a positive feedback loop. If we offer an incentive like staking interest though, holders (large and small) are likely to lock up some of their cash for that reward. This will prevent them from being able to sell for a guaranteed amount of time (penalties currently undecided). In theory and generally in practice too, that means no major price dips. This is good for in-verse users because it adds predictability.
Alden 18-Dec-21 06:26 PM
I also saw a question earlier about how it affects people who don't currently hold NCR or who hold very little. It benefits them by attempting to prevent a situation where they've paid a certain dollar value for NCR and then immediately lose that value due to market movement. It extends the time horizon for market movements, which is important for a currency. You don't want your dollar to be worth three dollars ten minutes from now, and worth 30 cents tomorrow -- you want it to be worth relatively the same amount as what you started with for as long as it can be.

FIGHT ME 18-Dec-21 06:57 PM
For any crypto bros who complained that we didn't vote to burn the 10 million coins. I'm not sure they realize that staking those coins removes them from circulation, (which removes them from being traded), which has a similar positive effect on supply and demand that burning those coins would have had. Regardless if the coins are staked or burned, they will be off the market either way, making less coins available to be traded, and theoretically creating a higher demand and a positive effect on price. It just so happens that staking also rewards long term holders with more coins, which is good for them personally, but good for long term market stability because it incentives people to keep holding long term to gain more coins instead of selling to dump the price. (edited)

Alden 19-Dec-21 07:58 PM
More or less Tangle is saying that the in-verse marketplace doesn't exist right now, so there's nothing to make NCR useful. He's also saying that staking alone won't make the token any more useful, even though it will in theory help stabilize the price. He's essentially saying that right now NCR doesn't have any uses other than as a speculative investment, and that's being summarized as "utility". (edited)
I think what he's getting at is that we either need to get NCR into the mix and start making it do work as a currency in Neos, or we need to switch paradigms and start looking at it as some kind of investment vehicle. I think he makes a good point, because right now we're in limbo. We're calling it a utility token, but it's functionally just a speculative investment, and staking alone won't solve that problem.
Where I disagree with him is that I think even modest success where locking up the price is concerned will have a qualitatively positive impact on NCR price fluctuation, and I think that in turn will enable more regular use in-verse. I think we're just going through some growing pains right now.

Jam10o 26-Dec-21 10:18 PM
yeah, most address formats do actually - Ethereum is one of the only networks that are hipster and use raw hex addresses (but if you see those Ethereum addresses with random characters capitalized, that's a checksum format)
ofc there's no point in using checksums if wallets don't... check them. and unfortunately in EVM/eth land, few wallets do. But this is a Solved Problem in most of the broader ecosystem. Polkadot even has different address formats for the same public key depending on which part of the greater network you are in (just for extra protection, even if technically you can recover funds sent to your public key on another network using your private key) (edited)

I personally don’t know many people that have issues with any “incorrect” addresses or sending issues. There is also ENS if that’s an issue. I’m also not going to get caught up in this too much as it’s a low friction point for anyone in crypto. I primarily use MetaMask as my interface, and if you don’t input an address correctly, it will show its not a valid address. The likely hood of an address in existence with 1 digit difference is such a minuscule edge case that is not worth discussing or typing any further about
ENS is like having “Banane9.ETH” or you can have unstoppable domains to have Banane9.crypto, etc. then it’s more custom. However if someone makes Banana9.ETH, there is a chance I type that incorrectly, similar to email when sending to someone with a slightly different spelling. So proper addresses seem to be very reliable imo

Jam10o 28-Dec-21 03:28 PM
protections on transfers don't work unless they're universal. Thom's point is that the protection is not universal - if you put a lowercase address in metamask asks no question if you make a typo that is still valid hex. And if other wallets don't generate checksummed addresses to begin with, there's no protection there either. On the blockchain, mistakes are permanent. That's not a "don't use crypto" thing, it's a "crypto isn't going to be used" thing. if you check out https://ncase.me/trust/ as a basic illustration, you'll see it will point out that in situations were interactions are risky and potentially unreliable, you quickly lose the ability to trust wether something went wrong due to a mistake, or if something went wrong due to malicious intent, making it difficult to develop trust - in the system, nor the other parties operating in it. If you want crypto to be something that people trust, it needs to be more reliable than legacy systems, uncompromisingly so. There is a depressing lack of empathic product people in this industry. (edited)
The Evolution of Trust
an interactive guide to the game theory of why & how we trust each other
